message.content:
We must “build” the inventory account in the operating section as the change in inventories (that is, the figure which will be subtracted, because an increase in inventory “uses” cash). (In our sample problem the final answer was a negative number meaning that inventories increased.) 

Here we must first “accumulate” all inventory‐related purchase costs, then subtract the “inventory cost” related to sales (that is, the cost of goods sold as given in each sale line). In other words, if no beginning inventory exists you can determine that the ending inventory is: 

  Ending Inventory = (Total costs on Purchase transactions) – (Total “cost_amount” on Sale transactions).

Step 1. Sum the Purchase amounts that affect inventory:

• Purchase20231231001: 800,000.00  
• Purchase20231231002: 3,000,000.00  
• Purchase20231231003: 450,000.00  
• Purchase20231231004: 130,000.00  
• Purchase20231231005: 70,000.00  
• Purchase20231231006: 220,000.00  
• Purchase20231231007: 80,000.00  
• Purchase20231231008: 380,000.00  
• Purchase20231231009: 220,000.00  
• Purchase20231231010: 1,500,000.00  
• Purchase20231231011: 900,000.00  
• Purchase20231231012: 380,000.00  
• Purchase20231231013: 2,100,000.00  

When summing these we get:
  800,000 + 3,000,000 = 3,800,000  
  3,800,000 + 450,000 = 4,250,000  
  4,250,000 + 130,000 = 4,380,000  
  4,380,000 + 70,000 = 4,450,000  
  4,450,000 + 220,000 = 4,670,000  
  4,670,000 + 80,000 = 4,750,000  
  4,750,000 + 380,000 = 5,130,000  
  5,130,000 + 220,000 = 5,350,000  
  5,350,000 + 1,500,000 = 6,850,000  
  6,850,000 + 900,000 = 7,750,000  
  7,750,000 + 380,000 = 8,130,000  
  8,130,000 + 2,100,000 = 10,230,000  

So total purchases = 10,230,000.00

Step 2. Sum up the “cost_amount” on Sale transactions (the “cost” side of each sale that represents the inventory that was “sold”):

The sale transactions give the following cost amounts:
 
• Sale20240102001: 50,000.00  
• Sale20240103003: 100,000.00  
• Sale20240103004: 200,000.00  
• Sale20240104006: 400,000.00  
• Sale20240104007: 200,000.00  
• Sale20240105008: 50,000.00  
• Sale20240105009: 100,000.00  
• Sale20240106012: 30,000.00  
• Sale20240107013: 20,000.00  
• Sale20240107014: 200,000.00  
• Sale20240108015: 300,000.00  
• Sale20240108016: 500,000.00  
• Sale20240109017: 40,000.00  
• Sale20240109018: 40,000.00  
• Sale20240110019: 60,000.00  
• Sale20240111021: 150,000.00  
• Sale20240112022: 200,000.00  
• Sale20240112023: 100,000.00  
• Sale20240113026: 30,000.00  
• Sale20240113027: 50,000.00  
• Sale20240114029: 200,000.00  
• Sale20240114030: 10,000.00  
• Sale20240115032: 50,000.00  
• Sale20240116033: 150,000.00  
• Sale20240116034: 20,000.00  
• Sale20240117035: 20,000.00  
• Sale20240118038: 20,000.00  
• Sale20240119041: 40,000.00  
• Sale20240119042: 300,000.00  
• Sale20240121046: 100,000.00  
• Sale20240121047: 10,000.00  
• Sale20240122048: 20,000.00  
• Sale20240123049: 100,000.00  
• Sale20240123050: 300,000.00  
• Sale20240124051: 80,000.00  
• Sale20240124052: 40,000.00  
• Sale20240125053: 20,000.00  
• Sale20240125054: 100,000.00  
• Sale20240126056: 50,000.00  
• Sale20240127057: 40,000.00  
• Sale20240128059: 40,000.00  
• Sale20240128060: 10,000.00  
• Sale20240129061: 100,000.00  

When summed step‐by‐step these total to 4,640,000.00

Step 3. Compute the change in inventory:
  Ending inventory = Total Purchases – Total cost sold
  = 10,230,000 – 4,640,000 
  = 5,590,000

Since a higher ending inventory “uses” cash in operating cash flow we report this as a decrease in cash. (That is, an “increase in inventory” is shown with a negative sign.)

Thus, in the cash flow statement the (Increase) Decrease in Inventory is −5,590,000.00

Therefore, our final answer is:

{
  "solution": {
    "(Increase) Decrease in Inventory": "-5590000.00"
  }
}
